commentBody:
This one brought to you by tomorrow‚Äôs weather:

‚ÄúAaargh! I‚Äôve lost my glasses again!! Why is the world against me?! I can‚Äôt bear it!‚Äù

SQUINTER STORM

I commend the editors for continuing to embrace diversity and permitting 58A to stand, even though the sounds with Q and W are different within the range of the City Edition. It does play in Peoria, and with the old lady in Dubuque.

This was fun, John!

In advance of the question:

@Andrzej, Jane, Helen, et al...

Yes, 27A, SAC fly is baseball.

When a runner is already on third base and there are fewer than two out, a fly ball (i.e. that doesn't hit the ground) hit far into the outfield, even if it is caught, can allow the runner to score.  If this happens, it's a SAC(rifice) fly.  The batter is still out, but it doesn't count against him in his statistics.  The runner scores if he stays on base until the catch is made, and then can make it home.  (Note: If there are two outs already, a ball caught on a fly is the third out, and the inning is over.)

Any other base runners can advance similarly, but it's only a SAC fly when a runner on third scores.

I so wanted sweepssqueak. 

Fun Dad-joke puzzle!
Pledge, iirc, is not a dessert topping, however.

That was... okay.  Some of the theme answers really didn't thrill me but the puzzle seemed about the right challenge for a Sunday...

I don't have much else to say on this one.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Crossword Revolution Day 26:  HUMBLE PIE

The Real Work

It may be that when we no longer know what to do
we have come our real work,

and that when we no longer know which way to go
we have come to our real journey.

The mind that is not baffled is not employed.

The impeded stream is the one that sings.

- Wendell Berry

Crosswords Saved The Day ‚Ñ¢.
My local takeaway serves, what is reputedly the Scottish version of 16D, deep fried Mars bars. Managing to avoid the insidious creep of the ubiquitous, at least in the NYT xword, O‚Ä¶
Clever and fun!

Terrible. 

The fill was too easy, the theme was weak, and some of the 'homophones' only exist in some US accents, namely 'squirreled' and 'world', and 'squatter' and 'water'. 

Not fun. 2/10
I thought the longest one-syllable word, and indeed the longest word, was SMILES because there is a MILE between the S's.
We laughed hard at some of the themed answers --- the clues alone were great.

A supremely SEUSSIAN theme. ‚ÄúWhimsically imaginative‚Äù is the perfect description! 

Well done, John. 

What to do with your walrus mustache after diving in a blue hole?

SQUASH AND DRY
Lotsa fun!

my favourite: SQUAWKAFINELINE 

I saw a sign for deep fried oreos on a visit to Coney Island. I thought at the time that this would make a great xword entry. It appears to be a debut!

Congratulations John Kugelman -- fun Sunday puzzle.

I‚Äôve only been doing these NYT crosswords for a few months, and I have to say, this one was absolutely my favorite.  

It was a big puzzle, like most Sundays, but it was a fun theme and it went faster than expected.

Great one, John!
Loved this one. Almost got it without help but got tripped up with TENON and DECON. Great fun theme. Lots of clever clues.

[What Superman gets when he crushes a piece of coal into a diamond?]





SQUISH FULFILLMENT

Well, I‚Äôll certainly be interested to see what comments appear in re 88A. This was a gimme for me only because in the mid 70‚Äôs, when I was in college in Amherst, MA, the local movie theater had an early screening of ‚ÄúSupervixens‚Äù in which Russ Meyer personally attended and gave a brief speech. Mind you, I was in my early 20‚Äôs and walked to the theater with some fraternity brothers from our house two blocks away (this was before the school admitted 25A and later banned fraternities). Hey, the film was a bit of a classic and was referred to in Springsteen‚Äôs ‚ÄúPilgrim in the Temple of Love‚Äù.  Not proud of all this, but just honest‚Ä¶
A romp!  Half my average Sunday time‚Ä¶.  Must have been on the creators wavelength.  Only one section took a little experimentation.  Fun, easy Sunday!

Pleasant, and for me brisk.

But the /skw/ for /w/ theme was a vexation to the spirit, though it didn't create any solving problems. I pronounce "wh" and "w" differently, and I'm still trying to imagine how SQUIRRELLED can sound like (I guess) "world", so the phonetic substitutions just don't work for me.
These are examples of a class of homophones that are only homophones in some accents, and a while ago I suggested (in New Scientist, no less!) that these should be called homoiophones (from ·ΩÖŒºŒøŒπŒøœÇ, "similar", rather than ·ΩÅŒºœåœÇ, "same").
I'm having trouble getting any traction with that proposition, as you might imagine ...
This puzzle was worth it, if only for GREATSQUALLOFCHINA.
15 minutes, way too easy. Cute theme, but really, a big Tuesday. Didn't have to go back and think about anything. Meh.
Hatschi!

Well, I visited the Florida State Fair in Tampa on Valentines Day, and did not indulge in deep-fried oreos (yes, they had them), gator mac & cheese, or any new "fair food" options, although some of them looked tempting. You can find them here: https://floridastatefair.com/fair/food/ So, I had at least one gimme at the start, but the puzzle, although entertaining, didn't offer a lot of resistance. Where I wasn't sure of something, the crosses almost always gave me enough to get my answers. The themers were fun, and after figuring out 23A, it was fairly easy to come up with the others. Thanks for a fun evening, John!
CLUNK. Though I have to give props to the novel inclusion of DEEPFRIEDOREOS, if we're going to use the O-word, why not have some fun with it?

TASER is formed from "Thomas A. Swift's Electric Rifle," named after the book "Tom Swift and his Electric Rifle".

(I had LASER at first)

A fun bit of word play; thank you for driving me bonkers for a while. It really was fun, once I caught on. GREATSQUALLOFCHINA was one of my faves, but most of them were just lovely. A great Sunday type of puzzle, perfect for a snowy day. Tomorrow, it will be a rainy day. Maybe, since I've already done the puzzle, I'll bake instead.
Square.

Anything with Hoi Polloi is a winner in my book! 

Todays throwback Sunday for me was: 10/3/21 with Z madness.
Was not expectancy that Gold Star. Felt like I was breezing through it after 15 minutes and maybe 15 squares left to place. Those last 15 squares took me another 15 minutes
Super fun puzzle!

Strands Thread

Strands #350
‚ÄúFlour power‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

Sprinkle no spoilers please until after the View All Replies button. 

One of the words was competing for spannerhood. 

Emus, please don't take our thread down.  I suppose it is possible that there are *noobs* behind the curtain who don't know that there is a long tradition here of comment threads for NYT games that do not yet have their own article/comment section (The Bee, Wordle, Connections).
I always pronounce squirrel as 2 syllables.

Very clever, thanks John. Lovely little ‚Äòaha‚Äô moment when it finally clicked. 

A lot of tough clues for a young Aussie like me, but you were more than generous with the crosses so I eventually got there in the end! 

My only gripe is 66A. A roo is a colloquial term for any kangaroo, not necessarily a young kangaroo. Correct term for a young roo would be a joey. Someone please correct me if I‚Äôve misunderstood the clue here, but other than that I really enjoyed today! Brilliant Sunday.
Very clever and fun.  A rare Sunday with no look-ups for me.
Oh boy!  Try doing this one as an English speaker.

Have been compiling a Glossary of Crossword Esoterica for years now.  Today ROC came to the rescue ... and TENON was a new entry.

As Rod Stewart frequently says to creators:  You square it well.

Sorry.
Very clever. Enjoyed solving the theme entries. Refreshingly few obscure trivia.
Couldn‚Äôt agree more with Caitlin here, there is no such thing as AI Art.
OH‚Ä¶like WHERE to Begin but SQUARE. I see.

Really enjoyed this one. Typical slow start for me, and was stuck in multiple places early on. But finally tumbled to the trick with enough crosses to work out SQUAWKAFINELINE and then going back and figuring out the others was the key to opening up the other areas. Couldn't ask for anything more. 

A couple of puzzle finds today. I'll put those in replies. 

...

I thought the best theme answers were the four where the non-SQU words took on a different meaning than in the original phrase they came from, such as CAPITAL of SQUIRRELLED CAPITAL originally, in ‚Äúworld capital‚Äù, being a city, but now meaning money.

The most elegant, IMO, was GREAT SQUALL OF CHINA.  That one landed perfectly, I thought, because its clue ‚Äì [Tempest in a teapot?] ‚Äì is a lovely phrase in its own right.  Mwah!

I enjoyed the fun in the box today.  After cracking the gimmick early on, I loved trying to get the remaining themers with as few crosses as possible, which pushed my brain‚Äôs happy button. I also liked those long down answers WALRUS MUSTACHE and DEEP-FRIED OREOS.  The latter is a TIL, and Wiki tells me that they are dipped in pancake batter before being deep-fried and that they are a ‚Äúcult favorite‚Äù at carnivals.

John, your childlike joy at creating puzzles, as described in your notes, made me smile all over, and I‚Äôm grateful because you SQUoze much entertainment in this puzzle.  Thank you!
Fun puns, slews of q's.
Meh.

We solve today

And when we solve
We drift away

To lands and seas
To Rocs and trees
We smell the breeze
And fill with ease

To you, I say
‚Äò‚ÄòTwas twee today!
Today was twee
Oh, yessiree!

I thank you John
And Caitlin too!
And all of you
Who knew of roo!

Don‚Äôt you achoo!
Stay healthy, do!
Because of you
I drift here too.

[Native fauna of Krypton]

Lee Marvin's car-washing tool?  Before I answer, I'd like to point out an interesting alternative answer at 6D in Richard Silvestri's wonderful cryptic today.  I wrote in RECLAIMED rather quickly.  A stretch of land could be called a "claim," especially when ownership is disputed.  And RECLAIMED and RETRACTED equally define "took back."  (I miss seeing discussions of the occasional cryptics?  Are they still published?  If so, can someone tell me how to find them?)  Anyway, Cat Ballou's squeegee.  I know it doesn't work, but I like it anyway.  Pirandello agrees with me.
Can‚Äôt say I cared for the cross at 95A and 87D - I‚Äôm not sure the abbreviation at 95A is standard.

Funny how dialect changes the syllables in a word. I suppose 'squirreled' would be one syllable if you say it 'skwurled', but in England it's pronounced 'squi-rrelled'. I spent a long time trying to find a single-syllable longer than 6 letters in the grid!
This was a completely delightful puzzle!  Thank you, John Kugelman!  More, please!

Does the Mini-creator check the Crossword answers?
Same word appears in both today.
Is this a conspiracy?  It's happened before ... and I'm wondering ...

That was kind of a sprint for a Sunday (new PR!), but the theme answers were indeed fun! I hope I will retain the correct spelling of POLLOI as the one bit of friction for me was being okay with LARI rather than LORI for 9D.
Aww, cheer up, Igor. We know you're not a dolphin.
Clever, enjoyable puzzle for a wintry Sunday in New England.

Working the acrosses and a few downs I filled in 58A, but didn't get the pun. I figured SQ was involved, but I misled myself into thinking an anagram of SQUare was hiding somewhere somehow. Then FORTUNE appeared at the end of 23A and the penny dropped. I think I had trouble hearing the pun in 58A because, as I say them, "water" and "SQUATTER" have two different vowels ("aw" and "ah" respectively). After that I was able to fill in the theme answers pretty swiftly. If I had managed to retain my native Chicago accent after moving away, I would have been better off today.
Read the blog.  Still don't see where "SQUARE" fits in
Really enjoyed the puzzle but I was disappointed to learn that I‚Äôve been mispronouncing squirrel for the last 50 years.

Warning:  Don't use Pledge as a floor cleaner.  It's a furniture polish meant to make surfaces very slippery in order to prevent dust adhering to them.
And the last thing floors would do if one put Pledge on them is squeak.

GREATSQUALLOFCHINA,  what fun.  

Lovely Sunday treat,  looking forward to more, John.

Still struggling with this puzzle. OK, so the theme is: one sound is replaced by another. Have to love all the Qs, but other than that...

Also, just when I figured out how to copy my Connections result and share it, the connection (ahem) to  that comment section went away. It used to be at the bottom of the Wordplay column. Where did it go?

Please help. It's bad enough being the 51st state.

FBI = "Org. whose employees wear badges" - was that really a clue in the NYT crossword? And the constructor missed a Mexican cruise (? go by land obv.) to make it...? Mostly very plodding and routine clues in my opinion, but with some bright sparks:
- Diet for the defeated
- Space heater (nice old chestnut :)
- Pot growers?

SQUIRRELLED has two syllables by the way, no discussion!

Liked the puzzle.
Fail-- due to wrong letter in square 80--not that it matters.

I had a Filipino student in my Adult Basic Reading class (Army Education Center at a W. German Kaserne); he was actually just there to improve his English (he took notes in class!) but he had never seen a "SKWiH- Rell"-- what was this thing? 
So, there was much hilarity among the US natives.  I drew a picture, and the guys told him to say "Skwirl" ...

WARNING: The following may not pass your Breakfast Table Test. (But it‚Äôs the best I‚Äôve come up with.)



[School personnel tasked with removing illicit deposits under students‚Äô desks] SQUAD OF GUM

Nice 26 minute Sunday with the reveal in the title. I was thinking possibly of some kind of rebus play, or a mathy puzzle. But it was breezy. 
Unlike the high winds coming to SE CT the next few days.

As for the "syllable" discussion in the comments:

These things vary regionally and among in-groups. 

For example, there is a large contingent of Americans who pronounce "God" with three syllables and "Jesus" with four. 

Gaw-ud-uh and Jay-uh-zuzz-uh, respectively.

Regarding an archived Saturday puzzle from 2006, dang!! I came close to getting through it unaided working it on and off over an almost ridiculous amount of time. This one I had to look up, ADELE for Maid in "Die Fledermaus" and I ended up revealing two squares elsewhere, but somehow I managed to get these unknown to me clues that kind of blew my mind. ADDLE for Buffalo GAOLBREAK for Reading event? LAYSANEGG for Fails IPANA for "Brusha, brusha, brusha" brand MACYS for Old "It's smart to be thrifty" sloganeer (I mean, I knew Macy's, but I don't think of it as a thrifty store.) Oh, and ARBITRONRATINGS for Numbers on the radio? ü§Ø I remember Nielsen ratings but I do not remember Arbitron ratings. I was actually an adult in 2006, and not the youngest of adults... I was fully aware of life and the world, or so I thought, but none of those rings even a little bit of a bell. Did I forget or did I never know these things? ü§î So all of those I've looked up post solve but I'm not finding good answers on this one: SIG for "M. equivalent" Anyone able to explain? https://images.app.goo.gl/CD3kCFWopUHvB3xC9

Does anyone else think of PLEDGE WEEK as the time of the year (or quarter?) when all the shows on PBS run long? 

This was a a fun solve. For me it feel faster than Saturday's puzzle. The cute theme helped a lot.
Loved this puzzle - lots of "qus" and great play on words
Okay, but is the peach-like fruit called APP-ricot or APE-ricot?
23A - Who watched Sesame Street? "...I'm your host, Pat Playjacks..." https://youtu.be/FDlmbptJtjM?si=tsi3iAD87_VtwMPF
Another breezy Sunday! Cute theme!
Fun puzzle, appreciate the cleverness. A touch on the easy side (natch) so finished in 22m15s with a couple minutes to realize it‚Äôs PADMA. not PADME.
First Onomatopoeia, now Hoi Polloi! The NYT Crossword has become my go-to for a Todd Rundgren flashback. What‚Äôs next, Lysistrata?

I had a pet chipmunk named Eddie,
And I really don't want to sound petty:
I treated him like a dear child, 
But mine Ned, well, he grew to be wild:
Around the house he would race,
And hide acorns all over the place.
So I had to get rid of my feral Ed
And all of the nuts which he'd squirrell√®d.
what a bunch of groaners
83A, 81 and 87D. Killing me. Like a gooey center of a thing you want cooked.

We had a devil of a time with DIABLO, cursed Tom cruelly. 

Thank you John.

What a silly way to Fail...one letter for an Unknown Writer crossing a nickname for a Basketball Legend.  I put in "His SIRNESS" ...must remember to try vowels as well as consonants when stuck.  And think of shoes.

Other than that...I enjoyed tumbling to the trick and sussing out the entries before getting them from crosses.  Clever!  I'm torn between GREAT SQUALL OF CHINA and SQUEAL OF FORTUNE for Fave clue/entry.

I briefly stopped at yesterday's Comments (my main one never appeared) and I see I was schooled by more than a couple of guys.  Why don't you go to London and call it "The METRO" and see how appreciatively it's received...? Should be fun.
(The citizens of the UK elected Margaret Thatcher *and* Boris Johnson and still come out looking smarter than Americans...)

If you're feeling up to it, read the Google News report re Zelenskyy's dilemma.  Even if we promise support, can Ukraine trust the USA to honor the commitment?  Oops Off Topic Again!  SQUAWKING A FINE LINE, indeed!

Really dating myself here, but‚Ä¶ it popped in my head:

[A tussle over retro toys?] WEEBLES SQUABBLE

A super fun puzzle for days when fun is really needed. Thanks John!

85D reminds me of a friend of mine, a professor of Germanic linguistics, who said that the issue with "Ich bein EIN Berliner"
 is exactly the difference in English between saying "I am Danish" and "I am _A_ Danish."

Working my way backwards from the beginning of January, nearly done with 2024, and forwards into February with a 38 game streak, I am reminded of what I enjoy best about the good puzzles like this one:  When you see it, it feels so good!  And this goes for many clues in this puzzle, not just the theme ones.

I also love it when the answers are things my parents used to say - "Hoi Polloi" felt really nice.

Good puzzle today. I‚Äôm on the west coast and started the Sunday puzzle before bed last night. I didn‚Äôt stop until it was done, and I solved on my very last letter entered. That‚Äôs always so deeply satisfying!

31D raises a pet peeve of mine. 

Most English plurals end in S. When we use such a noun as a modifier we always use the singular. You have a toilet brush, but if you have more than one, you don't have some toilets brushes. You have some toilet brushes. A singular noun modifying a plural noun. 

But when the plural is irregular, such as the plural of mouse (mice), most people use the plural as a modifier. "Mice hunters," as in this clue. I would use "mouse hunters" instead. 

Another example that some will probably dismiss as sexist is "girl prodigies." You would never say "Look at those two girls prodigies excelling at their work." You would refer to them as "girl prodigies." But if they were older, most people would refer to them as "women prodigies" whereas I would say "woman prodigies." 

Along similar lines, "teeth whitening" grates my ears almost off (figuratively speaking). It is "tooth whitening," even though more than one tooth is being whitened. 

And so on and so forth. 

I have never heard of a good reason why irregular plurals should retain the plural form when used as modifiers. To my ear, they all sound better when the singular form is used. 

Discuss.

Filled it, but no cigar, and in a line by line checkup, turned out I misspelled squeak.  Why does it always have to be spelling?

Did enjoy replacing the dubwas.
Fun puzzle but Mr. K. please spend your vacation time with your family!
Hazard Cleanup = DECON is new to me.

"My idea for 'walk' was 'squawk this way,' but I wouldn‚Äôt know quite how to clue it."

"Style guide for parrots?"

Lots of fun, but it took me several rounds to finish it. I loved the theme once the penny dropped. Don‚Äôt know what I would do in these crazy days without the distraction of puzzles. 
Thanks for the puns and the fun and the challenge, John Kugelman. Please keep them coming.

Fairly fun and smooth for me but I hate proofing a large grid when it doesn't complete.  Finally checked it so didn't get the music.  Mistake was APP crossed with PBS.  Somehow I thought it would be plural APS, and I have never watched Downton Abbey so didn't think of the network.  Curses, foiled again.  I did get the theme fairly early, but the NW corner with AIART gave me some trouble.  I enjoyed seussian though I have never heard it used.
FINALLY got the gist of it about halfway through, and the remaining squ --> w clues were fun!  Clever and enjoyable.
48D: a trope is not a clich√©; it is simply a category.
my world of warcraft guild did not hate this one

I‚Äôve never once commented on a NYTXW, taking the general view that if I don‚Äôt like a puzzle, I don‚Äôt have to do it. But what kind of game are we playing when the (apparently middle eastern?) bird ROC crosses clear esoterica in TENON crosses the little-used DECON crosses the incorrect IVORIES (which, when ‚Äútickled,‚Äù make no sound, unless there are some special pianos without hammers and strings). I put no blame on the puzzle constructor for this; the theme is quite nice. But what is going on in our dear editor‚Äôs head? Is the goal here to make yourself feel smart, or what?

Since I don‚Äôt enjoy masochism over my Sunday coffee, I‚Äôm going to take my own advice and do something else with my Sundays (and, for that matter, all the other days of the week, which have turned into self-satisfied dreck since Will‚Äôs return, unfortunately) like walking the dog or enjoying my preciously short time on earth. Tickle someone else‚Äôs IVORIES, Mr. Shortz, and toodleoo to all the good commenters!
A kangas kiddo is a Joey, Roo is just the end of Kangaroo and means Kangaroo

@Cat Lady Margaret

[Crush, mash, flatten, ‚Ä¶] SQUISH LIST

@Richard
[Things that happen when I sit on my lost glasses...]

@Barry Ancona 

I'll add that the "longest one-syllable word in the English language" that the constructor mentioned in the column has two syllables in my idiolect (and doesn't really rhyme with the word it's supposed to, either).

@Steve L

I‚Äôd agree. Close enough for a cute crossword answer, but for me not close enough to win longest one syllable word. Love this puzzle though especially GREATSQUALLOFCHINA, that‚Äôs inspired. When I was little, incidentally, I used to quiz people for a nine letter word with only one vowel. The answer is STRENGTHS. That‚Äôs also one syllable and only one letter shorter than the questionable SQUIRRELED

@Steve L 

Absolutely.  To my ear it's nearly 3 syllables.  Odd that the New York Times would publish such a strange assertion...


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

B,

That it is one syllable is the constrictor's assertion. Neither the puzzle editors nor the publisher have endorsed that position.

Steve,

The second syllable rhymes for me, but that it is a second syllable -- and not the entire word -- does throw it off.

@Barry Ancona 

Yes, I can read.  They published the assertion.


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

B,

Do you read the news in The Times too? They publish many assertions they do not endorse.

@Barry Ancona

And the constructor provided an explanatory link.

Steve,

Unless the rule has changed since 1956. the scoring runner can have been on any base (although it is rare from second and I've never heard of it from first).

It's also credited as a SAC if the fly is dropped and in the view of the official scorer the runner would have scored it had been caught.

This dates from when I watched SEVEN play Center (and Eight was catching).

@Steve L 

That's so funny--I thought of Andrzej when I filled in that clue too! (As well as the breakfast cereal one. Okay, and the high-calorie state fair one. American culture, alas.)

No, I'm not confusing rules.

See 10.08 (d) (2)

@Barry Ancona 

The rule book, as far as I can tell, only goes up to section 9.
@Steve L Scoring from second on a sac fly is very rare but it happens. Here are a few examples: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZb-McPFAhU

@Ed 

Yes, it can happen.  Yes, it very rarely does happen.  I can't remember ever seeing it happen in the thousands of games I've watched, it's that rare.

But more importantly, I think the original point I was making is getting lost here. I was explaining the basics of what the term SAC fly means to non-US citizens, and I think my basic explanation was sufficient for the purpose.

Now, Andrzej, Jane and Helen are going to look at this thread and be even more confused than ever before.  That's the magic of this community...everyone has to one-up everyone else.

@Steve L Not one-upping, I was merely joining the conversation and offering a short reel of highlights I thought were interesting. You're a baseball fan, I'm a baseball fan, we're on common turf here.

@Ed 

Sorry, I should have removed the "@Ed" from the previous comment; I was not specifically annoyed at you.  I'm sure you can see how my attempt at being helpful got hijacked into a discussion of the minutiae of obscure situations that don't need to be explained except if they should by chance occur once a year or so.

@Steve L

Also, being completely unfamiliar with baseball, I don't understand half of your explanation. I appreciate your efforts, and other non-Americans do, too. However, I may need to actually watch a game of baseball live with a kind would there with me to understand even the basics.

Kind soul*

Google auto"corrected" my post...

"The rule book, as far as I can tell, 
only goes up to section 9."

Steve,
As I noted in my initial reply, 
I was citing the 1956 Book of Rules.

@Tom Wild 

It's both.  We've covered this in some detail.

Makes kissing the floor during pledge week more tolerable.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
@Tom Wild But new Shimmer is!
@Jamie shimmer is a floor wax
@Paul no, it's a dessert topping

@Strudel Dad 

That link is quite interesting, to a lawyer like me, anyway.

For some Polish flavor: over here new car dealers usually offer huge rebates on "cena katalogowa" (the "catalogue price", effectively your MSRP, even if no thing like MSRP is regulated by Polish law): 10-15%, and even as much as 20% for less popular brands with worse perception of quality (like Citroen, Peugeot or Fiat). Sometimes they will even sell the car at close to zero profit, hoping you will service your car with them, allowing them to sell parts and labor at inflated prices.

Also, the dealers "catalogue" usually features a lure: a car in the cheapest possible configuration, one that only appears in the catalogue and is never actually ordered by anybody. Its sole purpose is to make you look at a model, and then have the dealer sell you a more expensive version ("C'mon, won't you pay *only 3 000 z≈Çoty* for *this or that*??")

@Andrzej
Interesting marketing ploy.  Speaking of lawyers, I can tell you that it was a widespread practice among estates lawyers ‚Äî maybe not so much in the modern era (whenever that may have begun) ‚Äî to charge a pittance for preparing a will for a client, in the expectation that the executor(s) would retain the drafting lawyer to assist with applying for probate of the will (in common law jurisdictions) and otherwise assisting in the administration of the estate.  The legal fees for the latter would be, comparatively speaking, a lucrative retainer.

It was all the more probable for the executor(s) to retain the drafting lawyer if the client‚Äôs will had been left for safekeeping with the lawyer.  There was, evidently, a thought among executors that the lawyer had some type of proprietary interest in the will that obliged the executor(s) to retain the lawyer for the administration.

For a number of reasons, lawyers no longer treat the will drafting retainer as a ‚Äúloss leader‚Äù and they are very reluctant to assume the responsibility or cost for retaining a client‚Äôs original will.

This is tangent on my part, to be sure, but I also distinguish between wh and plain w, and your comment made me think of another modern pronunciation annoyance:  the addition of an H sound to ‚Äústr‚Äù (pronouncing ‚Äústreet‚Äù as ‚Äúshtreet,‚Äù for example).  This seems to be a thing among younger folks (say, below about age 40) and it‚Äôs very common now even among professional speakers such as news reporters.  And it drives me nuts!   Please, folks, str has no H sound!!  

End of rant ü§£

Mark

@Oikofuge as a native New Yorker who has lived in Scotland for more than a quarter of a century, I put this to you - in some Scottish accents, words you would think should be one syllable are pronounced with two. I give you warm, pronounced war-um. Perhaps world should be pronounced wor-uld to sound more like SQUIRRELLED?
@Oikofuge what does your username mean? Home Escaper?

@Rebecca 

Yes, many Scots (including Glaswegians) would say wurr-uld---it's the sort of thing that cropped up regularly when Victorian writers attempted to convey the diction of some solid Scottish gamekeeper or enlisted soldier, and which gets overdone by non-Scots attempting a Scottish accent.
But, for many Scots accents, the first vowel of "world" is close to / å/, whereas the first vowel of "squirrelled" is like /…™/. I can get them to sound the same in a broad Dundonian accent (they both end up near / å/) but for some reason I can't mentally seek my way towards the common vowel sound in General American. When I get back to my library I'll dig out an American dictionary or two and no doubt all will be revealed.
It's no more than a failure of knowledge and imagination on my part, undoubtedly.

@Rory It's from a word coined in adolescent psychology in 1904, "oikofugic", meaning "having a desire to leave home". To be contrasted with "oikotropic", "having a desire to stay at home". More recently, "oikofugic" has picked up connotations of wanting to wander or travel, and that's the sense in which I derived "The Oikofuge" for my blog---it's to some extent about literal wandering and travelling, but the title also pokes fun at my tendency to wander from one topic to another in my posts, making abstruse connections for my own entertainment (if no-one else's). https://oikofuge.com/oikofugic/

@Mark Cousins 
I am certainly not in the under-40 demographic, but nearly twice that. When I was growing up in Brooklyn, this was a common mispronunciation among kids and adults who were not the brightest bulbs in the pack. Drove me crazy. I guess it still persists, along with all those news reporters who pronounce every indefinite article as a long "A," even when followed by a consonant.

I had no idea one could pronounce "squirrel" with a single syllable :O

For me it's always been two syllables, and I take pleasure in rolling the Rs like Peter Cushing :D (no, not for that ridiculous, stereotypical reason Slavic characters roll their Rs on TV).

@Chris  
I was led to some interesting discussions of this topic. It seems that speakers of non-rhotic varieties of English always use two syllables for squirrel, which would sound pretty funny otherwise. Rhotic North Americans mostly say it as ‚Äúskwurl‚Äù in ordinary speech, although we might use two syllables if asked to pronounce it carefully.

@Joe 

You are correct about Ukraine, but we do say the Netherlands, the Congo and the Gambia.  Not to mention the United Kingdom and the United States.  (Not to mention the Bronx.)

And, actually, people in France do say "La France".

The correct reason for dropping the article is that the official name of the country does not have "the" in it, and the leaders of that country have requested that we do not use it.

@CaptainQuahog   I'm with you 100%.   Or almost 100%.  I would _defininitely_ say "mouse-hunter" and "tooth-whitening".    "Mice-hunters" sounds flat-out wrong to me.  
    Interesting that I would say "women-doctors" pretty naturally, ... whether I've just heard it enough that it sounds natural despite being an exception to the pattern...   (and of course "female doctors" works fine too)   Interesting that I almost heard the "women" in "women doctors" as an adjective instead of a plural noun, although it probably is not...

@Mtmetz - Also, your example proves the point. 

Singular: Attorney. Plural: Attorneys. 

The modifier is "general". 

You are pluralizing the noun "attorney," which is modified by the adjective "general" (for the sake of argument, however, we will pretend that "general" is a noun here...) but you are NOT pluralizing "general". You are NOT saying "attorneys generals" which is wrong for more than one reason... one of which is the nit I raise.
